title: Carrot Consumption and Weight
question_text:
A researcher thinks there may be a negative correlation between the number of carrots an individual consumes and that individualâ€™s weight.
The researcher surveys $250$ randomly selected females and asks each her weight and how many servings of carrots she consumes per month.
The researcher also surveys $250$ randomly selected males and asks them the same questions. A scatterplot is made with different symbols for male and female data.
The study done by this researcher is:

choices.text: An experiment with a block design, blocking on gender.
A matched pairs experiment where a male could be paired with a female of similar weight.

solution:
When no treatment is imposed, and one is simply observing behaviors, it is an observational study.

Explanation of Distractors

Choices 'A', 'B', and 'E' are incorrect; each of these selections implies an experiment; however, even though males and females are separated, this is not an experiment since we are not imposing any treatment.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; for it to be a census, the entire population would have to be polled. This is not the case in this situation.
